title: Is Hermione Granger a badly written character? - Quora

response.answer_text: Absolutely! Being relatable doesn’t always mean a character is written well. Hermione starts off very relatable to all the little girls out there who preferred the company of books to that of people; the little girls who were swotty know-it-alls, who struggled to make friends, who had the teachers’ admiration but not that of the other students. Little girls who got bullied for their love of books - and wouldn’t you know it, Harry Potter was a book first, so that meant there was a big chance of said little girls picking up the book and immediately liking Hermione’s love of books - could see themselves in Hermione Granger, the intense, bossy little bookworm whose heart is in the right place and would give life and limb for her friends. For the first three books she’s rather great. She has buck teeth, which is often considered unattractive, like Ron’s red hair or Harry being scrawny. She makes mistakes which prove she is not infaillible. She crushes on the school’s most incompetent teacher who then turns out to be a chilling villain under all his goofiness, proving she is capable of lapses in judgement like everyone else. Prisoner of Azkaban is the book where she displays all the ways she needs to grow, from her stubborn pride that keeps her estranged from Ron for over a month because she just wouldn’t apologize, to her hatred of failure in that she’d rather quit a class than not succeed at it, as well as how she burns herself out with her trying to take every available class in the curriculum. Chamber of Secrets already had some sort of mini-arc for Hermione, to get her to stop believing in everything she reads in books, and Prisoner of Azkaban has now set up all the flaws she has and could grow out of over the course of the series. We could imagine Hermione experiencing failure and get a look into her insecurities, see how she fears Harry and Ron only keep her around because she’s useful for homework. This would make Hermione even more relatable and human, as well as reassure people like her when Harry… stands awkwardly to the side because he’s Harry - and Ron tells Hermione that she’s crazy and there’s no way she can think such rubbish is true, they’re her friends because… well he doesn’t really know but it’s certainly NOT because of her grades, she could be the biggest dunce in the school and they’d still want to hang around with her because she’s Hermione! She’s their friend and that’s the end of it. Stuck with them forever. They’re going to be glued to her worse than a gnome to a carrot! We could imagine Hermione’s pride ebbing away as she and her friends get into conflicts and she refuses to concede any points. The last time she did that in Prisoner of Azkaban, she turned out to be right but it was at the cost of Ron’s friendship (for a while); here just have her be flat-out wrong. Because she’s not all-knowing, she’s not almighty, and being clever and having good grades doesn’t prevent one from being wrong (don’t I know it).When I say that Hermione ought to grow past her pride, I don’t mean for her to sweep her intelligence under the rug to get accepted better, no way. I’m just talking about her learning to relent, about her learning to accept other people’s opinions, about her growing more tolerant and thoughtful. But hey, Rowling is the one steering the wheel! So let’s see how Hermione overcomes her flaws and grows as a character! So, how does she grow in Goblet of Fire? … She explains Ron’s feelings to Harry - she doesn’t get it right but Harry seems to accept her word as the truth - gets her buck teeth shrunk, and is courted by a famous athlete who gives her a perfect date and when she shows up at said date she’s so beautiful even the racist who hates her guts doesn’t insult her. … … … Yes hello Cinderesue nice to meet you. Uh. Ok. Alright. Ok. Um. Okaaaaaay well that was… something! No character development for Hermione at all, alright, totally fine, why not, ok. Why does she explain Ron’s feelings to Harry though, and especially why does Harry listen to her, it’s not like Hermione is known for being good with feelings - Ok whatever let’s go Order Of The Phoenix! She’s made prefect which has zero impact on the plot but gives Romione shippers plenty of opportunities to write missing moments fanfics, gets Harry to start the DA against his will - perfect, Hermione’s bossiness interfering with her friendships - and Harry turns out to enjoy it - nevermind! - forces Harry to conduct an interview with Rita Skeeter even though he had a date - ah, good, that is bound to create some conflict - and Harry… doesn’t react - nevermind!² - then she explains Cho Chang’s feelings to Harry and tells Ron he’s incapable of feeling emotions… and then she is scarring a student for life without repercussions, and pretty much never had anything wrong happen to her aside from being knocked out at the DoM due to her own dumb mistake that is never expanded upon. …………….. Ok, alright, why is Hermione suddenly giving out free psychology lessons now? Why the eff has she become the go-to for feelings stuff? Maybe because she’s the only one of the trio with some romantic experience but come the eff on, one date does not a love expert make. And she was already doing that in GoF so that makes no sense - Ok ok ok Half-Blood Prince maybe there’s finally something that takes her down a peg or two because so far I haven’t seen anything like growth from Miss Granger - Hermione attacks Ron with canaries because he hurt her feelings.……………just… gonna… get back to that… later…Hermione displays her tremendous lack of faith in Ron’s abilities to succeed by himself, which greatly harms their relationship but most of the blame is pinned on Ron instead because Ron’s feelings matter less than Hermione’s in Rowling’s narrative; Hermione is angry with Harry because she considers he’s cheating to get better Potions grades even though he offered to share the book with her, she thinks the HBP’s book was written by someone bad, she even tries to make Harry feel guilty about it JUST AFTER DUMBLEDORE’S DEATH WHAT THE EVERLOVING F*CK HOW IS THAT GIRL CONSIDERED THE “SENSITIVE” ONE, she turns out to have been right with absolutely no call-out of her behaviour.Also she attacked Ron with canaries and is never confronted for it. ……………………………. b o i Okay so Hermione didn’t… get anything resembling a character arc or whatever for the past three books. Alright. Well let’s hope Deathly Hallows will change that? Better late than never I mean? Like, Ron’s character arc which was hinted at in the first book, then surfaced back in the fourth, then a bit in the sixth - though how humiliating him repeatedly and hammering his self-esteem down to the Earth’s core is supposed to teach him that his insecurities don’t define him eludes me - and it’s set to conclude in this one, so let’s see - Hermione Obliviates her parents so they won’t be in the way, but it’s okay they’re not characters anyway; Hermione is so pretty that she now gets cat-called by men on the street; Hermione is the only one who has done some packing for the Horcrux Hunt because she’s the only one who’s gone camping before…? But in Goblet of Fire Harry and the Weasleys went camping - ok fine whatever, she saves Harry’s life but breaks his wand but his life is saved so it’s not that bad… Ah, yes, it seems she HAS learned something after all! Yay character growth!She has learned that she can beat Ron up with her fists and threaten to send canaries at him and that he won’t fight back because his self-esteem is so low in the dumps he just accepts it.Yay character growth???!!!??!? She insists that the Deathly Hallows can’t possibly exist in spite of the fact that she was perfectly willing to admit that all legends had some truth to it in Chamber of Secrets, so she actually regressed mentally; she gets tortured by Bellatrix Lestrange but she’s up and about a few hours later so it might have well not had happened; she finally stops using mind games with Ron and just kisses him (yaaaay, now can you learn to not hurl canaries at him?); and in the Epilogue she again shows that she doesn’t exactly trust Ron’s abilities and then is proved right because Rowling is… Rowling. Ok. So Ron is married to HBP!Hermione. Nice. Nice. I’ll just, um, call the police. Anyway. See anything resembling… change, mistakes, growth, lessons learned? Yeah me neither. And that’s a badly-written character.

Yes. I like Hermione, she’s clever and determined and strong. She can be scornful, a perfectionist and insensitive. Those are her qualities, good and bad. She’s a good character, but she is badly written. I don't think you can separate her character’s qualities from the narrative, because the way she is written is the way that the narrative presents her. When the narrative ignores or excuses her more questionable behaviour, as readers we are supposed to do the same. Shielding a character from question or criticism is bad writing, in my opinion. Hermione has great potential, and I think she is well-written in the first few books. In PS especially, she goes from being awkward, bossy and condescending to recognising the importance of friendship and bravery over intelligence and books. She still is incredibly clever and never loses her determination to be academically brilliant, but she starts to develop more social skills etc. Her consistent flaws are: a lack of emotional intelligence which can make her insensitive, fear of failure/expecting too much of herself and freezing under pressure. However, in the later books Hermione becomes more and more immune to criticism. What starts as Hermione/Ron bickering equally turns into “Hermione and Ron argue a lot, but it’s always Ron’s fault and he is always meaner”Hermione can be insensitive because she cares too much about logic (e.g. Lavender’s rabbit) becomes, “Hermione is factually correct so it doesn’t matter if she’s rude” (e.g. her scorn of Luna that gets overlooked, refusing to listen to the actual house elves but just calling them brainwashed and trying to trick them into being freed)Hermione uses advanced magic to jinx a contract without telling anyone it could permanently disfigure them if they break it? “Brilliant”Hermione attacks one of her best friends, unprovoked while he is defenceless? Narrative emphasises the fact she is upset, so fans blame the victim (Ron)Hermione freezes under pressure becomes Hermione consistently and reliably pulls the trio out of danger in every situation with a spur-of-the-moment plan and idea. Granted this could just be a development of character, except there’s no arc for that. It just happens.Hermione is academically brilliant but isn’t very emotionally intelligent becomes Hermione can reliably explain other people’s complex emotions even when she has never had a conversation with that person about how they are feeling (e.g. Cho).Bonus points as emotional intelligence is one of Ron’s strengths that he loses and Hermione gains.Writing out a character’s flaws, with no explanation or demonstration of them working to overcome them is lazy. Protecting a character even when they are in the wrong is bad writing. Favouring one character to the detriment of another is bad writing. If you do those things, you will end up with fans who glorify the character and refuse to even contemplate any criticism about them… or with fans who are sick of them never being called out and so feel the need to loudly point out those flaws to everyone else…
